Roadmap

Backend Implementation Plan: Feature Completion ‚Äã

Audience: Backend Engineering Team, Product Managers Objective: This document outlines the plan to move the backend from an architectural shell to a fully functional, feature-complete product by implementing all stubbed business logic.

Last Reviewed: 2025-11-20 Document Owner: Backend Lead

English ‚Äã

1. Priority & Goal ‚Äã

The #1 priority for the company is to complete the core business logic of the backend. The architecture is sound, but the application is not functional until these use cases are implemented.

  • Goal: 100% of use cases implemented and covered by E2E tests by End of Q1 2026.

2. Implementation Roadmap & Task Breakdown ‚Äã

This work will be broken down by domain.

Phase 1: Producer & Batch Management (High Priority) ‚Äã

  • Responsible: Backend Team A
  • Features:
    • Full CRUD for Producers.
    • Full CRUD for Certifications.
    • Full CRUD for Batches.
  • Ticket Example (Jira/GitHub):
    • Story: [API] As a PRODUCER, I want to CREATE a new Batch.
    • Sub-tasks:
      • [API-101] Implement CreateBatchUseCase with validation logic.
      • [API-102] Implement PrismaBatchRepository methods.
      • [API-103] Write unit tests for CreateBatchUseCase.
      • [API-104] Write E2E test for POST /api/v1/batches.
      • [API-105] Document endpoint in OpenAPI spec.

Phase 2: Traceability Event Workflow (High Priority) ‚Äã

  • Responsible: Backend Team B
  • Features:
    • Registering new TraceabilityEvents for a Batch.
    • (Planned) Integration with IPFS for file uploads associated with events.
    • (Planned) Integration with Blockchain service for anchoring event hashes.
  • Key Consideration: This workflow is the core of our "verifiable trust" value proposition and must be architected for immutability and high throughput.

Phase 3: Public & Buyer Endpoints (Medium Priority) ‚Äã

  • Responsible: Backend Team A
  • Features:
    • Implement public, read-only endpoints for viewing a batch's full history.
    • Implement necessary endpoints for the BUYER role.
  • Security Note: These endpoints must be carefully designed to prevent leaking any sensitive producer or operational data.

3. Definition of Done (DoD) ‚Äã

A use case is not considered "done" until it meets the following criteria:

  • [ ] Functionality: The business logic is fully implemented according to product requirements.
  • [ ] Validation: All input is rigorously validated using Zod schemas.
  • [ ] Testing:
    • [ ] Unit tests are written for the use case and any complex domain logic.
    • [ ] Integration or E2E tests are written to validate the full request-response flow.
    • [ ] Code coverage for the new module meets or exceeds 80%.
  • [ ] Documentation:
    • [ ] The API endpoint is documented with examples in the official OpenAPI/Swagger specification.
    • [ ] Any complex business rules are documented with code comments.
  • [ ] Internal Demo: The feature has been successfully demoed to the product manager and another engineer.
